previewParagraphs: Bologna’s steady climb into the Serie A top five has not come by accident. Built on control, clean sheets and a clear identity, Andrade Davis Nicolas’ side now faces a Cremonese outfit searching for stability and goals. With one team quietly establishing European credentials and the other trying to halt a worrying slide, this meeting at the Dall’Ara looks like a test of maturity for the hosts and resilience for the visitors.

These two clubs do not share a long, intense Serie A storyline, but their latest clash in Bologna offered a useful reference point. The last time Cremonese visited the Dall’Ara in the league, the match finished in a draw, giving Bologna a home record of 0 wins, 1 draw and 0 losses from their last 1 home encounter against the Grigiorossi. That stalemate underlined how awkward Cremonese can be to break down when they stay compact, and it lingers as a reminder that Bologna, for all their progress, still have to work hard to convert dominance into victories against well-organised visitors.

Bologna enter this match in quietly imposing shape. Over their last 6 matches in all competitions, they are unbeaten with 3 wins, 3 draws and 0 losses. They have averaged 1.67 goals scored and only 0.5 conceded per game across that spell, suggesting a strong balance between attack and defence. The performance data backs that up: around 12.67 total shots per match, with 3.83 on target and an average possession of 55.67% shows a side that tends to control the ball and create a steady flow of chances rather than relying on chaotic spells.

At home, Bologna’s last 3 fixtures have been even more defensively assured. They have 1 win, 2 draws and 0 defeats, scoring 0.67 goals per game but conceding none. The goal output is modest, yet the clean sheet record highlights how difficult it has become for visiting sides to find a way through at the Dall’Ara. They still average 12.67 shots and 3 on target with the same 55.67% possession at home in that short run, pointing to a consistent pattern of control even when the scoreboard has not always fully reflected their superiority.

Cremonese’s recent path contrasts sharply. Across their last 6 matches in all competitions, they have 1 win, 2 draws and 3 losses. They are scoring 1 goal per game and conceding 1.33 on average, with 10.33 shots per match, 3.67 on target and roughly 49.17% possession. That paints a picture of a team that can create enough to be competitive but often finds itself on the wrong side of fine margins, especially defensively.

The trend becomes more concerning when we stretch the sample. Cremonese have drawn 5 of their last 10 matches in all competitions and lost 4 of their last 8. Crucially, they have been winless in 11 of their last 11 matches in all competitions, an 82% winless rate in that sequence, and they come into this game on a run of 3 straight defeats and 3 straight matches without a victory. Stopping that slide against one of the league’s more settled outfits will require a significant improvement in both penalty-box areas.

In Serie A, Bologna’s season so far looks firmly like that of a top-tier side. They sit 5th after 12 league games, with 7 wins, 3 draws and only 2 defeats. They have scored 21 goals, an average of 1.75 per match, and conceded just 8, or 0.67 per game, giving them a healthy goal difference of +13. Those numbers are not built on a short burst either. Over their last 40 league matches they have won 50%, and they are undefeated in 83% of their last 12 Serie A fixtures. At home in the league, they have won 63% of their last 40 games and are undefeated in 90% of their last 20, recording clean sheets in 50% of those 20 home encounters. This is one of the most reliable home records in the division.

Cremonese, by contrast, are sitting 11th after 12 league matches. Their Serie A record reads 3 wins, 5 draws and 4 losses, with 13 goals scored, an average of 1.08 per match, and 16 conceded, 1.33 per game, for a goal difference of -3. It is not disastrous, but it illustrates a side that struggles to outscore opponents and often ends up sharing points or narrowly losing. Their broader trend, with extended winless sequences in all competitions, suggests that turning performances into consistent results has been a persistent issue for Davide Nicola’s men.

Bologna’s long-term statistical profile is impressive. In all competitions, they have won 50% of their last 16 matches and drawn 50% of their last 6, underlining a habit of avoiding defeat. They have remained undefeated in 87% of their last 15 matches in all competitions and are currently undefeated in each of their last 11 games, a 100% undefeated run in that span. They have also recorded wins by 2 or more goals in 38% of their last 13 matches in all competitions, and that same 38% rate holds across their last 13 league games, showing that when they get on top, they often do so with a measure of comfort.

At home, the strength is even clearer. Bologna have been undefeated in 92% of their last 12 home matches in all competitions and have kept 7 clean sheets across their last 15 home outings. In Serie A at the Dall’Ara, they have won 63% of their last 40 matches and stayed undefeated in 90% of their last 20, with half of those games ending in clean sheets. These are the underlying numbers of a side that trusts its defensive structure and rarely collapses.

Cremonese’s main trend is almost the mirror image. Their last 10 matches in all competitions have brought 5 draws, underlining their tendency to be involved in tight games where neither side fully seizes control. However, with 4 defeats in their last 8 and that statistic of being winless in 11 of their last 11 matches in all competitions, confidence and momentum are clearly issues. Defensively they are not being overwhelmed, but their inability to string wins together leaves them vulnerable against teams with sharper attacking patterns.

previewParagraphs: Two teams searching for stability rather than headlines meet in Vallecas, with Rayo Vallecano trying to turn solid performances into consistency and Valencia looking to climb away from the lower reaches of La Liga. The numbers suggest a tight, tactical contest rather than a spectacle, with both sides showing clear strengths and very obvious flaws.

Rayo Vallecano arrive in this match with the quiet confidence of a side that has become very hard to beat, especially at Estadio de Vallecas. Iñigo Pérez’s team sit 11th in La Liga with 4 wins, 4 draws and 5 losses, but that mid-table label hides some impressive underlying trends, particularly on their own pitch, where control of the ball and defensive resilience have become a clear identity.

Recent history between these two in Vallecas leans slightly towards the hosts. In the last 6 home meetings in La Liga, Rayo have taken 2 wins, shared the points 3 times and lost only once. That means they have avoided defeat in 5 of those 6 fixtures against Valencia on this ground, a pattern that matches up neatly with their broader home record in the league.

Rayo’s broader form points to a team that knows how to stay in matches. Across their last 6 La Liga games they have 3 wins, 2 draws and just 1 defeat, scoring 1.67 goals and conceding 1.17 per match. In all competitions they have won 50% of their last 12 outings and have not been beaten in 9 of their last 11. At Vallecas the numbers are even more convincing: undefeated in 12 of their last 15 league home matches and registering 4 clean sheets in their last 10 league home fixtures.

The issue, however, is turning draws into wins. Rayo have drawn 53% of their last 15 home league games and are winless in 11 of their last 13 at home in La Liga. They are very hard to break down but often lack the ruthless edge to finish opponents off. The underlying performance metrics are strong: in the last 3 home matches they average 19 shots per game, 4.33 on target and 54.67% possession, conceding just 0.67 goals per match. The structure is solid, but the finishing touch is not always there.

Valencia, under Carlos Corberán, come into this one in a more precarious position. They sit 15th with 3 wins, 4 draws and 6 defeats, sharing Rayo’s 12 goals scored but conceding significantly more with 21 against, an average of 1.62 per game. That negative goal difference of -9 underlines a side that can be punished, especially away from Mestalla, where their long-term numbers are worrying.

Across all competitions, Valencia have lost 4 of their last 8 matches and 5 of their last 10 away. More striking is their away run: they have not won in 13 of their last 16 away fixtures. In the league they have lost 8 of their last 16 matches and failed to win in 8 of their last 10 La Liga games overall. Their recent sample in all competitions paints a picture of balance on the scoreboard – 2 wins, 2 draws and 2 losses in the last 6, with 1.17 goals scored and 1.17 conceded per match – but the long-term away pattern remains a major concern.

With the ball, Valencia are less dominant than Rayo. Over their last 6 fixtures they average 12.33 total shots and 3.83 on target, holding the ball for 49.67% of the time. Away from home, that drops further in terms of possession, and Corberán has often leaned on a more direct, transition-based approach. That fits with their player profile in attack but risks ceding the initiative in Vallecas against a Rayo side happy to keep the ball and probe.

previewParagraphs: Stadio Olimpico is set for a clash of contrasting strengths as league leaders Roma, ruthless at home and miserly in defence, face a Napoli side reshaped under Antonio Conte and built to punish the smallest lapse. With both teams in the top three and separated by fine margins in the table, this meeting has the feel of a test of how sustainable each project really is.

Roma arrive in this match carrying the authority of a side that has turned results into a habit. Top of Serie A with 9 wins and 3 losses from 12 games, they have done it with control rather than chaos, scoring 15 goals at an average of 1.25 per game while conceding only 6 at 0.5 per match. That defensive platform has underpinned a run where they have been undefeated in 82% of their last 38 league fixtures and particularly dominant at the Olimpico, winning 27 of their last 40 home games in Serie A.

The recent numbers sharpen that picture even further. Over their last 6 matches in all competitions, Roma have 5 wins and 1 loss, scoring 1.67 and conceding just 0.5 per game. Their play has been structured around possession and sustained pressure: an average of 15.33 total shots, 5.5 on target and 58.33% possession. At home across the last 3 outings those figures rise to 17 shots, 6 on target and 62% possession, evidence of a side comfortable pinning opponents back and keeping them there.

Napoli, for their part, travel with solid credentials of their own. Conte’s team sit third with 8 wins, 1 draw and 3 defeats from 12, scoring 19 goals at 1.58 per game and conceding 11 at 0.92. Stretch the lens to 40 league matches and Napoli have won 60%, remaining undefeated in 85% of their last 20 Serie A outings. Those numbers reflect a side that has learned to manage games with maturity, often controlling tempo through midfield and striking with precision when chances appear.

However, the away form tells a more nuanced story. Across their last 10 away games in all competitions, Napoli have lost 50%, and in their last 6 away matches they have been winless in 5 of those 6. Even more striking, they have lost by 2 or more goals in 43% of their last 7 away fixtures. While the overall Conte blueprint is clearly working, the team has not always transported its authority from Naples to hostile grounds.

The historical balance between the sides in Rome has been relatively even. In the last 5 league meetings at the Olimpico, Roma have taken 1 win, there have been 2 draws and Napoli have 2 victories. Broaden that to the last 10 home clashes for Roma against Napoli in all competitions and the hosts have lost 50% of those matches, suggesting that Napoli have often found ways to disrupt Roma’s rhythm in this stadium, even when the Giallorossi have been strong overall in the league.

Longer term trends give Roma reason for confidence. They have been undefeated in 21 of their last 26 home matches in all competitions and have won 26 of their last 40 home games overall, many of them with authority: 39% of their last 28 home fixtures in all competitions have been won by 2 or more goals. In Serie A alone, 38% of their last 21 home league matches have been victories by at least a 2 goal margin. Defensively, the profile is robust too, with 14 clean sheets in their last 30 home league games and average shots on target conceded kept under tight control.

Napoli’s broader data paints the picture of a high level side that occasionally leaves the door ajar. Across their last 40 matches in all competitions they have won 60% and been undefeated in 85%. Yet away from home, while there are 12 clean sheets in their last 30 away matches, the more recent pattern shows vulnerability, particularly when forced to chase games. A possession average of 52.67% away suggests they do not get overrun, but a shots on target figure of 3.47 hints at a more selective, transitional approach on the road.

originalTitle: Roma’s Relentless Home Form Faces Napoli’s Streetwise Conte Blueprint

previewParagraphs: A tense matchup sets the stage at Groupama Stadium as Lyon host Nantes in their Ligue 1 clash. Both sides have struggled for consistent results, but Lyon's commanding home record and Nantes' woes on the road may shape the outcome.

The Groupama Stadium is primed for Lyon versus Nantes, a fixture with intriguing recent history and significant implications for both teams. Lyon, anchored in seventh position, are looking to bounce back and reestablish themselves among the league's frontrunners. Nantes, traveling from fifteenth, face the dual challenge of lifting their season and overcoming a daunting away run.

Whenever Nantes travel to Lyon, the visiting side has found points exceedingly hard to come by. In their last five visits to the Groupama Stadium, Lyon have taken four wins and drawn once, maintaining an undefeated record on home turf against Nantes over that period. This home dominance reflects a keen ability to control direct matchups, with Lyon frequently managing to keep Nantes' attack at bay.

Lyon approach the encounter after a challenging stretch. They have managed only one win in their last six matches, alongside three draws and two defeats. Despite the low attacking returns, averaging just 1.17 goals per game in this period, their defense hasn't fared much better, conceding 1.5 per game. At home, however, Lyon have fared better, winning two of their previous three matches at Groupama, scoring an average of two and conceding just over one per game.

Nantes, meanwhile, have similarly claimed only a single victory in their past six outings, coupled with two draws and three defeats. Their attack matches Lyon’s in output at 1.17 goals per game, but their defense has proven more vulnerable, allowing two goals per match on average. Notably, recent home form for Nantes is more stable, but that statistic carries less weight as they head on the road, where winless runs have become a concerning trend.

After thirteen matches in Ligue 1’s regular season, Lyon hold a positive record of six wins, three draws, and four losses, with eighteen goals scored and fifteen conceded, yielding a goal difference of plus three. Nantes, in contrast, have won just twice, drawing five and losing six, and carry a minus seven goal difference, having conceded nineteen while notching twelve goals.

Statistical trends over a longer horizon paint a clearer picture of both teams’ momentum. Lyon have been undefeated in twelve of their last fifteen home matches in all competitions, a streak mirrored by their recent record in Ligue 1, where they have gone undefeated in sixteen of their last twenty at home. Clean sheets are also common, with four out of ten in recent home league games. On the flip side, their most recent overall record shows winless spells in six out of their last seven league matches.

Nantes’ main concern is a prolonged inability to claim wins on the road. They have been winless in sixteen of their last twenty away matches in all competitions and have lost half of their previous twelve away games. Furthermore, they have failed to win in seventeen of their last twenty-one competitive matches overall.

previewParagraphs: With both teams searching for stability in the Eredivisie standings, Ajax welcome Groningen to the Johan Cruijff Arena for a date that could shape their near-term domestic campaigns. With Ajax enduring a rough patch lately, there is a sense of urgency surrounding Fred Grim’s group, while Dick Lukkien’s Groningen look to capitalize on any lapses.

Ajax have found themselves in tough waters recently, collecting just one victory in their last six matches across all competitions, alongside one draw and four defeats. Their average goals scored per game in this period stands at 1.17, with a concerning 2.5 conceded. The home form is not much brighter. From their last three at the Johan Cruijff Arena, Ajax have claimed no wins, mustering only one point and averaging just 0.67 goals for and 2 against per match.

Groningen do not come into this clash with much better form, but there are signs of resilience. In their last six games, they've registered one win, two draws and three defeats, while scoring 1.17 and conceding 2.17 per match. Their approach has involved notably more shooting activity than Ajax, with 18 shots per match and 6.33 finding the target. However, these efforts have not always translated into points, and Groningen are also winless in four straight outings.

In their last 10 head-to-head encounters in all competitions, Ajax have a strong record, winning seven, drawing one and losing only two to Groningen. More telling is their dominance at home in this fixture, notably winning by a margin of two or more goals in all of their last nine home matches against Groningen. Their recent three meetings also edge Ajax’s way with two wins.

Ajax are currently 6th in the Eredivisie after 13 games, with five wins, five draws and three losses. They have scored 23 and conceded 19, maintaining a positive goal difference of four. The numbers show an offense averaging 1.77 per match and a defense occasionally breached but rarely overwhelmed.

Groningen sit just one place and a single point behind Ajax on the table, at 7th after 13 games. Dick Lukkien’s squad has recorded six victories, two draws and five defeats, with a matching tally of 19 goals for and 19 against. Their campaign has been characterized by streaky form and not much separating attack from defense.

Ajax’s struggle for consistency is clearly reflected in the trends. They've lost seven of their last 14 in all competitions and are winless in 83% of their last 12 fixtures. Even at home, their record shows no victories in 83% of the previous six outings. However, they have managed to keep clean sheets in 40% of their last 30 home league matches and remain undefeated in 80% of their previous 15 at home in the league.

Groningen, meanwhile, have not fared much better away from home, going winless in 16 of their last 20 matches on the road in all competitions. They have also lost three of their previous six league matches, but managed three wins from their last six away fixtures, giving them a better platform than their overall away trend would suggest.
previewText:
With both teams searching for stability in the Eredivisie standings, Ajax welcome Groningen to the Johan Cruijff Arena for a date that could shape their near-term domestic campaigns. With Ajax enduring a rough patch lately, there is a sense of urgency surrounding Fred Grim’s group, while Dick Lukkien’s Groningen look to capitalize on any lapses.

Ajax have found themselves in tough waters recently, collecting just one victory in their last six matches across all competitions, alongside one draw and four defeats. Their average goals scored per game in this period stands at 1.17, with a concerning 2.5 conceded. The home form is not much brighter. From their last three at the Johan Cruijff Arena, Ajax have claimed no wins, mustering only one point and averaging just 0.67 goals for and 2 against per match.

Groningen do not come into this clash with much better form, but there are signs of resilience. In their last six games, they've registered one win, two draws and three defeats, while scoring 1.17 and conceding 2.17 per match. Their approach has involved notably more shooting activity than Ajax, with 18 shots per match and 6.33 finding the target. However, these efforts have not always translated into points, and Groningen are also winless in four straight outings.

In their last 10 head-to-head encounters in all competitions, Ajax have a strong record, winning seven, drawing one and losing only two to Groningen. More telling is their dominance at home in this fixture, notably winning by a margin of two or more goals in all of their last nine home matches against Groningen. Their recent three meetings also edge Ajax’s way with two wins.

Ajax are currently 6th in the Eredivisie after 13 games, with five wins, five draws and three losses. They have scored 23 and conceded 19, maintaining a positive goal difference of four. The numbers show an offense averaging 1.77 per match and a defense occasionally breached but rarely overwhelmed.

Groningen sit just one place and a single point behind Ajax on the table, at 7th after 13 games. Dick Lukkien’s squad has recorded six victories, two draws and five defeats, with a matching tally of 19 goals for and 19 against. Their campaign has been characterized by streaky form and not much separating attack from defense.

Ajax’s struggle for consistency is clearly reflected in the trends. They've lost seven of their last 14 in all competitions and are winless in 83% of their last 12 fixtures. However, they have managed to keep clean sheets in 40% of their last 30 home league matches and remain undefeated in 80% of their previous 15 at home in the league.

previewParagraphs: Two sides trapped in long winless stretches meet in Bergamo with similar problems but different approaches. Atalanta keep the ball but struggle to turn control into goals, while Fiorentina are chasing their first league win of the season despite regular flashes of danger in the final third. The numbers suggest a match decided by small details rather than sweeping dominance.

Atalanta against Fiorentina brings together two teams whose seasons have drifted into the same current: plenty of effort, a lot of control in phases, but not enough victories. Raffaele Palladino’s Atalanta sit mid table, drawing more than they win, while Paolo Vanoli’s Fiorentina arrive in serious trouble near the bottom, still searching for that elusive first Serie A success of the campaign.

The most recent chapter between these sides came in Florence on 30 March 2025, when Fiorentina edged a 1-0 home win. The match was tighter than the score suggests. Atalanta actually saw more of the ball with 55% possession and produced 39 dangerous attacks compared to Fiorentina’s 20, but crucially failed to register a single shot on target from 10 attempts. Fiorentina, with 12 shots and 4 on goal, made their efficiency count. Moise Kean struck just before half time, finishing in the 45th minute, and that solitary goal decided a contest where Atalanta looked structurally solid but blunt in the penalty area. That pattern – territorial control without a cutting edge – still hangs over the Bergamo side.

In Serie A, Atalanta’s numbers underline their status as draw specialists. After 12 league matches they are 13th, with 2 wins, 7 draws and 3 losses. They have scored 14 and conceded 14, an average of 1.17 scored and 1.17 allowed per match, reflecting a side that tends to keep things balanced rather than chaotic. The goal difference of 0 mirrors the table: steady, but far from convincing.

Fiorentina, by contrast, sit 19th and are yet to win in 12 league outings. Their record of 0 wins, 6 draws and 6 defeats is stark, as is a goal difference of -9. They score 0.83 goals per game on average (10 in total) and concede 1.58 (19 in total). While they occasionally show attacking promise, they have been punished regularly at the other end, and their inability to turn tight games into wins explains their position more than any dramatic collapses.

Atalanta’s last 6 matches in all competitions read 1 win, 2 draws and 3 losses, with just 0.67 goals scored and 1.5 conceded per game. They still generate chances, averaging 13 total shots and 2.83 on target, helped by a strong average possession of 58.67%. At home in their last 3, they have 0 wins, 2 draws and 1 defeat, scoring only 0.33 goals and conceding 1.33. Interestingly, those Gewiss Stadium games show an even higher volume of attempts, with 17.67 shots and 3.33 on target on average, plus 60% possession, hinting that the finishing rather than chance creation is the main issue.

Fiorentina’s last 6 in all competitions show 0 wins, 3 draws and 3 losses, scoring 1 goal per game and conceding 1.83. They attempt 12.33 shots, with 3.67 on target, and hold 51% possession on average. Away from home they have struggled for a long period; in their last 8 away matches in all competitions they have been winless in 88%, drawing 4 and losing 4. Even so, their away defensive work is not entirely fragile, with 40% clean sheets across their last 10 away games, which supports the idea of low scoring battles rather than open shootouts.

Atalanta’s statistical profile is unusual. Across their last 12 matches in all competitions, 50% have ended level. In the league, the draw theme is even stronger: they have drawn 50% of their last 14 Serie A games. Despite a recent slump, they have been robust over the longer term, remaining undefeated in 32 of their last 40 Serie A matches. Yet within that, there is a prolonged dry spell: they have been winless in 11 of their last 13 league encounters. At home in Serie A they are traditionally strong, with 50% wins across their last 40 home league games and 80% of their last 10 at the Gewiss Stadium ending without defeat, though 80% of their last 15 home league matches have also been winless, underlining how draws dominate their record.

Fiorentina are heavily defined by their own winless run. In all competitions they have failed to win in 10 of their last 12 matches, while in Serie A they have been winless in 80% of their last 20 league games. Half of their last 12 league fixtures have ended in defeat, and half have finished as draws, reinforcing the picture of a team constantly on the edge but rarely able to tip matches in their favour. On the road, 4 draws in their last 8 away outings in all competitions highlight their capacity to keep things tight, even if results rarely swing fully their way.

originalTitle: Atalanta vs Fiorentina: Draw Specialists Set For Another Tight Serie A Duel

previewParagraphs: With both teams sitting at nearly opposite ends of the Bundesliga table and form telling two starkly contrasting stories, Eintracht Frankfurt host Wolfsburg at Deutsche Bank Park looking to tighten their grip on a top-six spot. The momentum is certainly with the hosts, but Wolfsburg may prove to be a stubborn opponent despite their recent slump.

Looking into recent history, Eintracht Frankfurt and Wolfsburg have met several times at the Deutsche Bank Park with mixed results for both sides. In their last five home encounters against Wolfsburg, Frankfurt have registered one win, two draws, and two losses. This record signals a degree of unpredictability whenever these sides clash in Frankfurt, yet the current context hints at a possible shift in momentum.

Frankfurt enter this contest carrying a robust six-match unbeaten streak in all competitions. They have picked up three wins and three draws in their last six games, conceding an average of just 0.83 goals and scoring 1.5 per match. Their home form is similarly encouraging – two wins and a draw in their last three, with only 0.33 goals conceded on average. That defensive solidity, combined with a forward line that creates 13.33 shots and 5.67 shots on target per game at home, will be an asset when facing Wolfsburg.

Looking at their overall Bundesliga campaign, Frankfurt sit sixth in the standings after eleven matches, having won six, drawn twice, and lost three. Their attack is consistently productive, averaging 2.45 goals per game, while their defense concedes two per match. Across their last 21 league matches, they've won eight times by margins of two or more goals, and remain undefeated in 83% of their past 40 home Bundesliga games – a sign of steady home resilience.

Wolfsburg, meanwhile, have struggled significantly, particularly in their most recent fixtures. They've picked up only one win in their last six matches and have lost the other five, scoring just 0.83 goals per match and conceding two on average. Away from home, Wolfsburg's recent record is slightly better with three wins in their last eight outings, but they have also failed to keep a clean sheet in four of those matches.

The league table reflects their struggles, as Wolfsburg are currently fifteenth after eleven matches. With only two wins and two draws, they've already suffered seven defeats, scoring 13 and conceding 21 for a negative goal difference of -8. The trend extends further back: Wolfsburg have been winless in 10 of their last 12 matches in all competitions and have not tasted victory in 82% of their last 28 league games.

Statistically, Frankfurt's 55% league win rate at home across the last 20 matches and an undefeated record in seven of their last eight league games highlight their consistency. Wolfsburg, conversely, have lost 58% of their last dozen Bundesliga matches and show little sign of reversing this downtrend in away fixtures. The recent four-match losing streak underscores a deeper loss of momentum, with defensive frailties continuing to hinder any revival.

previewParagraphs: A return to Stade Raymond Kopa sets the stage for an intriguing Ligue 1 face-off as Angers, solid at home recently, seek to test a high-flying Lens side enjoying one of their most productive spells of the campaign. With both teams jostling for position and pedigree, this contest could prove to be a telling juncture in their seasons.

Angers come into this encounter with a sense of quiet momentum. In their last six matches, they have recorded three wins and two draws with only one defeat, maintaining an impressive record of being undefeated in five of their last six outings. Angers’ home form looks even more robust, remaining unbeaten in their last three matches at Stade Raymond Kopa by winning two and drawing one, while conceding just 0.33 goals per game.

Lens, by contrast, have carved out a formidable run, chalking up five victories from their past six matches while displaying attacking verve with two goals scored per game on average. Their recent surge includes a current streak of three consecutive wins. Out of their last 12 games in all competitions, Lens haven't been defeated in 10, with a 75% win rate that highlights their credentials as one of Ligue 1’s in-form teams.

The recent head-to-head record between Angers and Lens presents a clear narrative. In the last three matches between these two sides, Lens have come out on top each time, taking all three points on every occasion. This dominance forms a psychological edge for Lens and underlines the challenge Angers face in overturning the trend.
Even looking further back at home fixtures, Angers have lost three of their last four home matches against Lens, suggesting the visitors have found a formula that works in this fixture.

In the current Ligue 1 table after 13 matches, Angers hold 11th place. Their record reads four wins, four draws, and five losses. The goal statistics point to a modest attack with only 11 goals scored, but they have balanced this with 15 conceded, keeping a goal difference of -4.

Lens, on the other hand, hold third position, underpinned by nine wins and an impressive goal difference of +11. They have found the back of the net 22 times while conceding only 11, which speaks to both attacking and defensive organization.

For Angers, clean sheets have played a pivotal role—they have managed to prevent their opponents from scoring in 40% of their last 10 home matches. They have also remained undefeated in six of their last seven home encounters. However, a 50% loss rate over their last 28 matches in all competitions hints at inconsistency over the longer term.

Lens have excelled not only in winning matches but also in maintaining form away from home, claiming victories in half of their last 20 away fixtures. Their 83% rate of being undefeated in the last 12 matches highlights their resilience and consistency.

previewParagraphs: LASK Linz prepare for a challenging encounter as Rapid Wien come to the TGW Arena in the Austrian Bundesliga. With both clubs fighting near the top of the standings, this fixture offers another twist in their competitive rivalry.

The last meeting between these sides offers plenty to analyze. Back on October 19, LASK Linz claimed a 2-0 away win over Rapid Wien in Vienna. Despite only owning 34% of possession and facing 49 dangerous attacks from Rapid, LASK were highly organized defensively. They limited Rapid Wien to three shots on target from twelve attempts and were more clinical with their own four shots on target out of fourteen. Early strikes from Moses Usor and Samuel Adeniran set the tone and helped maintain their hold on the match.

Rapid Wien's last defeat to LASK was marked by their inability to break down a compact backline, despite controlling the ball for much of the contest. LASK's efficiency and resilience in this encounter foreshadow potential tactics for the rematch at their own ground.

Form coming into this clash heavily favors LASK Linz. The hosts have won all of their last six in all competitions, while keeping a superb defensive record by conceding just 0.17 goals per game. Their home status is even more imposing, with wins in 60% of their last 15 league matches and clean sheets in 43% of their last 30 home league games. Impressively, LASK Linz have been undefeated in 13 of their last 15 home Bundesliga matches.

Offensively, LASK are averaging 1.67 goals scored per home game over their past three fixtures, while shots on goal remain consistent at nearly six per match. Defensively, their control has improved in front of their own supporters, allowing only one goal per match in the last three at home.

Rapid Wien, on the other hand, appear less stable in recent weeks. They have failed to win in 3 of their last 3 outings in all competitions and have a less potent attack averaging 1.17 goals per game over the last six matches. While they have managed to keep things relatively tight at the back, conceding just 0.83 goals per game recently, a trip to LASK is a stern test given their hosts' formidable momentum.

Looking at overall Bundesliga performance, Rapid Wien do sit higher in the standings at second place with 19 goals scored (1.36 per game) and a goal difference of +4 over 14 rounds. LASK Linz, in fifth, trail slightly with 17 goals (1.21 per game) and a goal difference of -1. The margins are tight and suggest a competitive battle, though LASK's home trends offer them the statistical edge.

LASK Linz have built a reputation for big home performances, winning by at least two goals in 38% of their last 13 home Bundesliga games, while also winning 40% of all recent matches by a similar margin. Rapid Wien's away form sees them winning 8 of their last 15 in all competitions, but they have dropped points too frequently, losing four times in their last eight Bundesliga games.
The defensive records from both sides in recent contests suggest a low-scoring affair, adding weight to the under 2.5 goals prediction.

Turning to the probable lineups, LASK Linz head into the game missing Lenny Pintor, Emmanuel Michael, Sasa Kalajdzic and Art Smakaj through injury, international duty or suspension. Dietmar Kühbauer is likely to maintain the 3-4-1-2 formation seen in the last three matches, fielding:

previewParagraphs: Viking FK host Valerenga at SR-Bank Arena on November 30, 2025 as they aim to extend an impressive run at the summit of the Eliteserien. With Valerenga contending with key suspensions and injuries, this meeting arrives at a crucial stage of the season.

The last time these two sides met, Valerenga delivered a strong performance at home, securing a 3-1 result over Viking FK. Valerenga held 52% possession and registered sixteen shots, five on target, matching Viking FK's shots on goal. The hosts were clinical through Elias Sørensen's opener in the 41st minute, followed by Hilmir Rafn Mikaelsson and a quickfire Henrik Bjørdal double. Viking FK had their moments with equal shots on target, but Valerenga's dangerous attacks and pressure told late on.

While Viking FK will remember Valerenga's efficiency in attack and ability to capitalise on opportunities, the away side will hope to replicate key elements of that victory—though they must do so without some influential names this time around.

Viking FK enter this clash in superb form, having won all of their last 6 matches and conceding only 0.5 goals per match during that spell. Their home record is equally robust, averaging nearly four goals per game across their past three at SR-Bank Arena.

Valerenga's recent results, in contrast, are mixed. Three wins, one draw and two defeats in their last six highlight inconsistency, and their away form is concerning—winless in six of their last seven road games. Scoring less than one goal per away game in their last three further illustrates their struggles outside Oslo.

In the league standings, Viking FK remain first, amassing 21 wins and producing 72 goals in 29 matches, with an impressive goal difference of +37. Their attack, averaging 2.48 goals per match, has set the pace in the Eliteserien this season.

Valerenga find themselves in seventh. With 12 wins, equal numbers of losses, and 48 goals scored and conceded, their form has oscillated all campaign, resulting in a zero goal difference and a mid-table finish with little margin for error.

Viking FK have not been beaten in their last 13 games in all competitions, and their overall record in the last 40 matches includes winning 73% of the time and being undefeated 35 times. At home, 87% undefeated in their last 15, and 53% of those saw them win by two or more goals.

Valerenga, meanwhile, show a trend of away difficulty: losing 9 of their last 18 on the road and going winless in 6 of their last 7 away games. Their goal output and defensive lapses have cost them valuable points away from home.
previewText:
Viking FK host Valerenga at SR-Bank Arena on November 30, 2025 as they aim to extend an impressive run at the summit of the Eliteserien. With Valerenga contending with key suspensions and injuries, this meeting arrives at a crucial stage of the season.

The last time these two sides met, Valerenga delivered a strong performance at home, securing a 3-1 result over Viking FK. Valerenga held 52% possession and registered sixteen shots, five on target, matching Viking FK's shots on goal. The hosts were clinical through Elias Sørensen's opener in the 41st minute, followed by Hilmir Rafn Mikaelsson and a quickfire Henrik Bjørdal double. Viking FK had their moments with equal shots on target, but Valerenga's dangerous attacks and pressure told late on.

While Viking FK will remember Valerenga's efficiency in attack and ability to capitalise on opportunities, the away side will hope to replicate key elements of that victory—though they must do so without some influential names this time around.

Viking FK enter this clash in superb form, having won all of their last 6 matches and conceding only 0.5 goals per match during that spell. Their home record is equally robust, averaging nearly four goals per game across their past three at SR-Bank Arena.

Valerenga's recent results, in contrast, are mixed. Three wins, one draw and two defeats in their last six highlight inconsistency, and their away form is concerning—winless in six of their last seven road games. Scoring less than one goal per away game in their last three further illustrates their struggles outside Oslo.

In the league standings, Viking FK remain first, amassing 21 wins and producing 72 goals in 29 matches, with an impressive goal difference of +37. Their attack, averaging 2.48 goals per match, has set the pace in the Eliteserien this season.

Valerenga find themselves in seventh. With 12 wins, equal numbers of losses, and 48 goals scored and conceded, their form has oscillated all campaign, resulting in a zero goal difference and a mid-table finish with little margin for error.

Viking FK have not been beaten in their last 13 games in all competitions, and their overall record in the last 40 matches includes winning 73% of the time and being undefeated 35 times. At home, 87% undefeated in their last 15, and 53% of those saw them win by two or more goals.

Valerenga, meanwhile, show a trend of away difficulty: losing 9 of their last 18 on the road and going winless in 6 of their last 7 away games. Their goal output and defensive lapses have cost them valuable points away from home.
originalTitle: Viking FK Look to Cement Top Spot Against Injury-Hit Valerenga
